document.title: Tauber’s theorem and Karamata’s proof of the Hardy-Littlewood tauberian theorem

para.p: The following lemma is attributed to Kronecker by Knopp. 1 footnote 1 1 footnote 1 Konrad Knopp, Theory and Application of Infinite Series, p. 129, Theorem 3.

If
→
b n
0
then

Math.text: (b _ 0 + b _ 1 + cdots + b _ n) / (n + 1) to 0

absent less= ((n _ 0 + 1) * K) / (n + 1) + ((n - n _ 0) * epsilon) / (n + 1)

absent less= epsilon + epsilon

para.p: We now use the above lemma to prove Tauber’s theorem. 2 footnote 2 2 footnote 2 cf. E. C. Titchmarsh, The Theory of Functions, second ed., p. 10, §1.23.

para.p: Also, using

Math.text: 1 - x ^ n = (1 - x) * (1 + x + cdots + x ^ (n - 1)) less (1 - x) * n

para.p: we have

Math.text: absolute-value@(((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(a _ n * (1 - x ^ n))) less= ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(absolute-value@(a _ n) * (1 - x ^ n))
absolute-value@(((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(a _ n * (1 - x ^ n)))
absent less= ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(absolute-value@(a _ n) * (1 - x ^ n))
conditional@(bra@((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N) * a _ n, (1 - x) * n)
conditional@(bra@((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N) * a _ n, (1 - x) * n)
absent = ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@((absolute-value@(a _ n) * n) / N)
absent = ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@((absolute-value@(a _ n) * n) / N)
absent = (((N + 1) / N) cdot (1 / (N + 1))) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(n * absolute-value@(a _ n))
absent = (((N + 1) / N) cdot (1 / (N + 1))) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(n * absolute-value@(a _ n))

absent less ((N + 1) / N) cdot epsilon

absent less 2 * epsilon

para.p: Now,

Math.text: absent = (((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(a _ n * (1 - x ^ n)) + ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(a _ n * x ^ n) + ((sum _ (n = N + 1)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n)) - ((sum _ (n = N + 1)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n) - s

absent = (((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(a _ n * (1 - x ^ n)) + ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n)) - s - ((sum _ (n = N + 1)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n)
absent = (((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(a _ n * (1 - x ^ n)) + ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n)) - s - ((sum _ (n = N + 1)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n)

para.p: and then

Math.text: absolute-value@(((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(a _ n) - s) less= absolute-value@(((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(a _ n * (1 - x ^ n))) + absolute-value@(((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n) - s) + absolute-value@(((sum _ (n = N + 1)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n))
absolute-value@(((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(a _ n) - s)

absent less= absolute-value@(((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(a _ n * (1 - x ^ n))) + absolute-value@(((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n) - s) + absolute-value@(((sum _ (n = N + 1)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n))
absent less 2 * epsilon + epsilon + epsilon
absent less 2 * epsilon + epsilon + epsilon

para.p: proving the claim. ∎

Let
: g
→
[ 0 , 1 ]
R
and
0 < c < 1
. Suppose that the restrictions of
g
to
[ 0 , c )
and
[ c , 1 ]
are continuous and that

Math.text: g * (c - 0) = (limit _ (x to c ^ -))@(g * x) less= g * c

para.p:
For
> ϵ 0
, there are are polynomials
⁢ p
( x )
and
⁢ P
( x )
such that

Math.text: formulae@(p * x less= g * x less= P * x, 0 less= x less= 1)

para.p: and

Math.text: formulae@((norm@(g - p)) _ 1 less= epsilon, (norm@(g - P)) _ 1 less= epsilon)

para.p:
There is some
> δ 0
such that
- c δ
≤ x < c
implies that

Math.text: g * (c - 0) - epsilon / 2 less= g * x less= g * (c - 0) + epsilon / 2

para.p:
further, take
< δ
ϵ
-
⁢ g
( c )
⁢ g
(
- c 0
)
and
< δ
1 2
.

Take
L
to be the linear function satisfying

Math.text: formulae@(L * (c - delta) = g * (c - delta) + epsilon / 2, L * c = g * c + epsilon / 2)

para.p:
For
- c δ
≤ x < c
,

Math.text: L * x - g * x = ((((L * x - g * (c - delta)) + g * (c - delta)) - g * (c - 0)) + g * (c - 0)) - g * x
L * x - g * x
absent = ((((L * x - g * (c - delta)) + g * (c - delta)) - g * (c - 0)) + g * (c - 0)) - g * x
absent = ((((L * x - L * (c - delta)) + epsilon / 2 + g * (c - delta)) - g * (c - 0)) + g * (c - 0)) - g * x
absent = ((((L * x - L * (c - delta)) + epsilon / 2 + g * (c - delta)) - g * (c - 0)) + g * (c - 0)) - g * x
absent less= (L * c - L * (c - delta)) + epsilon / 2 + epsilon / 2 + epsilon / 2
absent less= (L * c - L * (c - delta)) + epsilon / 2 + epsilon / 2 + epsilon / 2
absent = (g * c - g * (c - delta)) + (3 * epsilon) / 2
absent = (g * c - g * (c - delta)) + (3 * epsilon) / 2
absent = (((g * c - g * (c - 0)) + g * (c - 0)) - g * (c - delta)) + (3 * epsilon) / 2
absent = (((g * c - g * (c - 0)) + g * (c - 0)) - g * (c - delta)) + (3 * epsilon) / 2
absent less epsilon / delta + epsilon / 2 + (3 * epsilon) / 2
absent less epsilon / delta + epsilon / 2 + (3 * epsilon) / 2
absent less (2 * epsilon) / delta
absent less (2 * epsilon) / delta

para.p:
Define
: Φ
→
[ 0 , 1 ]
R
by

Math.text: Phi * x = cases@(g * x + epsilon / 2, 0 less= x less c - delta, maximum@(L * x, g * x + epsilon / 2), c - delta less= x less= c, g * x + epsilon / 2, c less x less= 1)

para.p:
Φ
is continuous and
≥ Φ
+ g
ϵ 2
. We have

Math.text: (norm@(g - Phi)) _ 1 = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@((Phi * x - g * x) * differential-d@(x))
(norm@(g - Phi)) _ 1
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@((Phi * x - g * x) * differential-d@(x))

absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ (c - delta))@((epsilon / 2) * differential-d@(x)) + ((integral _ (c - delta)) ^ c)@((Phi * x - g * x) * differential-d@(x)) + ((integral _ c) ^ 1)@((epsilon / 2) * differential-d@(x))

absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ (c - delta))@((epsilon / 2) * differential-d@(x)) + ((integral _ (c - delta)) ^ c)@((Phi * x - g * x) * differential-d@(x)) + ((integral _ c) ^ 1)@((epsilon / 2) * differential-d@(x))
absent less epsilon / 2 + ((integral _ (c - delta)) ^ c)@((Phi * x - g * x) * differential-d@(x))
absent less epsilon / 2 + ((integral _ (c - delta)) ^ c)@((Phi * x - g * x) * differential-d@(x))
absent less= epsilon / 2 + ((integral _ (c - delta)) ^ c)@(maximum@(L * x - g * x, epsilon / 2) * differential-d@(x))
absent less= epsilon / 2 + ((integral _ (c - delta)) ^ c)@(maximum@(L * x - g * x, epsilon / 2) * differential-d@(x))
absent less= epsilon / 2 + ((integral _ (c - delta)) ^ c)@(maximum@((2 * epsilon) / delta, epsilon / 2) * differential-d@(x))
absent less= epsilon / 2 + ((integral _ (c - delta)) ^ c)@(maximum@((2 * epsilon) / delta, epsilon / 2) * differential-d@(x))
absent = epsilon / 2 + delta cdot ((2 * epsilon) / delta)
absent = epsilon / 2 + delta cdot ((2 * epsilon) / delta)
absent = (5 * epsilon) / 2
absent = (5 * epsilon) / 2

para.p:
Because
Φ
is continuous, by the Weierstrass approximation theorem there is a polynomial
⁢ P
( x )
such that
≤
∥
- Φ P
∥
∞
ϵ 2
. Then,

Math.text: formulae@(g * x less= P * x, 0 less= x less= 1)

para.p: and

Math.text: (norm@(g - P)) _ 1 less= ((norm@(g - Phi)) _ 1 + (norm@(Phi - P)) _ 1 * bra@(limit-from@((5 * epsilon) / 2, +)) * Phi) - evaluated-at@(P, infinity) less= (5 * epsilon) / 2 + epsilon / 2 = 3 * epsilon

para.p:
On the other hand, take
l
to be the linear function satisfying

Math.text: formulae@(l * (c - delta) = g * (c - delta) - epsilon / 2, l * c = g * c - epsilon / 2)

para.p:
One checks that for
- c δ
≤ x < c
.

Math.text: g * x - l * x less (2 * epsilon) / delta

para.p:
Define
: ϕ
→
[ 0 , 1 ]
R
by

Math.text: phi * x = cases@(g * x - epsilon / 2, 0 less= x less c - delta, minimum@(l * x, g * x - epsilon / 2), c - delta less= x less= c, g * x - epsilon / 2, c less x less= 1)

para.p:
which is continuous and satisfies
≤ ϕ
- g
ϵ 2
. One checks that

Math.text: (norm@(g - phi)) _ 1 less (5 * epsilon) / 2

para.p:
Because
ϕ
is continuous, there is a polynomial
⁢ p
( x )
such that
≤
∥
- ϕ p
∥
∞
ϵ 2
. Then,

Math.text: formulae@(p * x less= g * x, 0 less= x less= 1)

para.p: and

Math.text: (norm@(g - p)) _ 1 less= ((norm@(g - phi)) _ 1 + (norm@(phi - p)) _ 1 * bra@(limit-from@((5 * epsilon) / 2, +)) * phi) - evaluated-at@(p, infinity) less= (5 * epsilon) / 2 + epsilon / 2 = 3 * epsilon

para.p: The following is the Hardy-Littlewood tauberian theorem. 3 footnote 3 3 footnote 3 E. C. Titchmarsh, The Theory of Functions, second ed., p. 227, §7.53, attributed to Karamata.

If
≥
a n
0
for all
n
and

Math.text: formulae@(((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n) similar-to 1 / (1 - x), x to 1 ^ -)

para.p: then

Math.text: s _ n = ((sum _ (nu = 0)) ^ n)@(a _ nu) similar-to n

para.p:
For any
≥ k 0
,

Math.text: (1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * x ^ n ^ k)
absent = (1 / (1 + x + cdots + x ^ k)) * (1 - x ^ (k + 1)) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ (k + 1) ^ n)
absent = (1 / (1 + x + cdots + x ^ k)) * (1 - x ^ (k + 1)) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ (k + 1) ^ n)
absent to (1 / (k + 1)) cdot 1
absent to (1 / (k + 1)) cdot 1
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(t ^ k * differential-d@(t))
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(t ^ k * differential-d@(t))

para.p:
as
→ x
1 -
. Hence if
⁢ P
( x )
is a polynomial, then

Math.text: (limit _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * P * x ^ n)) = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(P * t * differential-d@(t))

para.p:
Define
: g
→
[ 0 , 1 ]
R
by

Math.text: g * t = cases@(0, 0 less= t less e ^ (- 1), t ^ (- 1), e ^ (- 1) less= t less= 1)

para.p:
Let
> ϵ 0
. By Lemma , there are polynomials
⁢ p
( x )
,
⁢ P
( x )
such that

Math.text: formulae@(p * x less= g * x less= P * x, 0 less= x less= 1)

para.p: and

Math.text: formulae@((norm@(g - p)) _ 1 less= epsilon, (norm@(P - g)) _ 1 less= epsilon)

para.p:
Because the coefficients
a n
are nonnegative, taking upper limits and then using () we obtain

Math.text: (limit-supremum _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * g * x ^ n)) less= (limit-supremum _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * P * x ^ n))
(limit-supremum _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * g * x ^ n))
absent less= (limit-supremum _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * P * x ^ n))
absent = (limit _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * P * x ^ n))
absent = (limit _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * P * x ^ n))
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(P * t * differential-d@(t))
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(P * t * differential-d@(t))
absent less ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(g * t * differential-d@(t)) + epsilon
absent less ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(g * t * differential-d@(t)) + epsilon

para.p: Taking lower limits and then using () we obtain

Math.text: (limit-infimum _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * g * x ^ n)) >= (limit-infimum _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * p * x ^ n))
(limit-infimum _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * g * x ^ n))
absent >= (limit-infimum _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * p * x ^ n))
absent = (limit _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * p * x ^ n))
absent = (limit _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * p * x ^ n))
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(p * t * differential-d@(t))
absent = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(p * t * differential-d@(t))
absent > ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(g * t * differential-d@(t)) - epsilon
absent > ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(g * t * differential-d@(t)) - epsilon

para.p:
The above two inequalities do not depend on the polynomials
⁢ p
( x )
,
⁢ P
( x )
but only on
ϵ
, and taking
→ ϵ 0
yields

Math.text: (limit-supremum _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * g * x ^ n)) less= ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(g * t * differential-d@(t))

para.p: and

Math.text: (limit-infimum _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * g * x ^ n)) >= ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(g * t * differential-d@(t))

para.p: Thus

Math.text: (limit _ (x to 1 ^ -))@((1 - x) * ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * g * x ^ n)) = ((integral _ 0) ^ 1)@(g * t * differential-d@(t)) = ((integral _ (e ^ (- 1))) ^ 1)@(t ^ (- 1) * differential-d@(t)) = 1

para.p:
For
= x
e
-
/ 1 N
we have

Math.text: ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * g * x ^ n) = ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * e ^ (- n / N) * g * e ^ (- n / N))
((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * x ^ n * g * x ^ n)
absent = ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(a _ n * e ^ (- n / N) * g * e ^ (- n / N))
absent = ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(a _ n * e ^ (- n / N) * e ^ (n / N))
absent = ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(a _ n * e ^ (- n / N) * e ^ (n / N))
absent = s _ N
absent = s _ N

para.p: Thus, () tells us that

Math.text: (limit _ (N to infinity))@((1 - e ^ (- 1 / N)) * s _ N) = 1

para.p: That is,

Math.text: s _ N similar-to 1 / (1 - e ^ (- 1 / N))

para.p: and using
we get

Math.text: s _ N similar-to N

para.p: completing the proof. ∎
